‚ö†Ô∏è This competency framework is a demonstrative template

This framework demonstrates how to implement and operationalize a competency framework with CBE or SBA within Moodle's competency frameworks.
It follows a simple 7-steps synthesis of the development stages for competency frameworks including:
column2: defining competencies,
column7: and additional elements in the program like&nbsp
column8: learning and assessment situations

column1: It contains namings, self-explanations and self-instructions to identify and develop properly each component, which should, of course, not to be presented as it into the end-to-end framework.

column2: >‚ñ∂Ô∏è Before getting to grips with the approach, it's useful to take a look back at Tardif's (2006) definition of&nbsp
>&laquo
column4: >a complex know-how to act based on the effective mobilization and combination of a variety of internal and external resources within a family of situations »

column6: that students should develop throughout the training program.

column1: ‚úçÔ∏è Introduce with an action verb and in less than 20 words.
• ‚úÖ Ask yourself what are the complex activities that characterize the professional/graduate you wish to train.
• ‚úÖ Are they truly complex? Do they allow for varied combinations of resources to adapt to different situations?

• ‚úÖ Are they sufficient in themselves, or is their implementation in service of another purpose? Are they implemented ""for"" something else? If so, they are probably not competencies in the sense of Tardif (2006). However, the purpose they serve is likely one.
• ‚úÖ Do you recognize the professionals you wish to train in them? If not, complete or specify these know-how to act.

If you are planning to create severals competencies right here, start using a logical naming convention in order to develop a whole structured competency framework. I will be very useful later, for ordering or filtering list inside docs or tables, for integrating through learning management system (LMS like Moodle) because they recquire unique IDs for each elements that defines a competency, for quick Searching and or Replacing, for conventional mutual sharing, ...

column2: by...
by...
>&nbsp
column3: Define the essential components for action, which account for the complexity of the competency, inform on its quality, and facilitate its assessment.

column1: ‚úçÔ∏è Introduce with ""by..."", use of gerunds (complementing the action), between 3 and 6 per competency.
• ‚úÖ Ask yourself how one recognizes a competent person. How do we recognize the proper implementation of a competency?

• ‚úÖ Once the components are identified, characterize them: do they inform about the result (which must be socially acceptable), about the approach, about adherence to norms, about the nature of exchanges with other protagonists? Do these elements have consensus among teachers and professionals? If one of these elements is missing, do you not deem it appropriate to add it?
• ‚úÖ Are these components distinctly different from the know-how to act? Isn't this a repetition of the competency or other components? Are you able to discriminate them?

column2: >&nbsp
column3: ‚òùÔ∏è Define families of situations (often types of professional contexts) that account for the extent of the competency.

column1: ‚úçÔ∏è Use of nouns, between 2 and 4 Professional Situations per Competency.
• ‚úÖ In which contexts or situations will the graduate be required to implement the competency?

• ‚úÖ Do several of these situations share many common characteristics? Or do they require the implementation of very similar learnings? Situations that share common characteristics likely constitute a relevant ""family of situations.""

• ‚úÖ Among the selected families of situations, which are likely to generate a sufficient number of relevant situations in terms of the targeted learnings (which enforce interdisciplinarity, which require consideration of all components)?

column2: would let you continue the structured development using unique IDs for for each Competency (-Cx). and each subconsequent Professional Situations (-PSx)
...&nbsp
...&nbsp

>
‚òùÔ∏è Define some of the resources (knowledge, know-how, professional attitudes) that will be useful for developing competence.

column1:
Those would eventually be some of the materials that could be delivered through the course with activities and resources inside your Moodle's course.

Internal and external resources:
For Tardif (2019, p. 51):
&ldquo
column2: A resource is said to be internal insofar as it refers to what a person has already mastered, both in terms of cognition and in terms of attitudes and conduct, whereas an external resource relates to everything the person consults, examines and analyzes in his or her environment.&rdquo

column1: • ‚≠ê Apply the framework set to exercise the targeted competencies, but is unable to intentionally and repeatedly make relevant choices in the encountered professional situations.
• ‚≠ê Understand the main elements, but need support or advice to construct teaching or adjust behavior autonomously and responsibly.

column2: >&nbsp
column3: ‚òùÔ∏è Define the levels of competency development aimed for at the end of given learning periods.

column1: ‚úçÔ∏è Use of short expression, generally 4 levels following the NICA model (Novice, Intermediate, Competent, Advanced) of the targeted competency.
• ‚úÖ Reflect on the situations of competency implementation that the student might face at the end of a given period (for example, at the end of each year).

• ‚úÖ The complexity of these situations can be characterized by several variables such as: the number and type of parameters/protagonists to consider, an increasingly comprehensive or even systemic perspective of the contexts, the difficulty of reconciling the components, etc.
• ‚úÖ Define the role/function/posture/responsibility expected of the student for each of the selected contexts, in other words, for each level of competency development.
• ‚≠ê‚≠ê Has sufficient mastery of the basic skills required to act autonomously, anticipate and make appropriate professional choices.
• ‚≠ê‚≠ê Identify the relevance of own work in most situations, as well as professional ethics and ability to self-evaluate in order to improve practice continuously.

column2: >&nbsp
column3: ‚òùÔ∏è Define the levels of competency development aimed for at the end of given learning periods.

column1: ‚úçÔ∏è Use of short expression, generally 4 levels following the NICA model (Novice, Intermediate, Competent, Advanced) of the targeted competency.
• ‚úÖ Reflect on the situations of competency implementation that the student might face at the end of a given period (for example, at the end of each year).

• ‚úÖ The complexity of these situations can be characterized by several variables such as: the number and type of parameters/protagonists to consider, an increasingly comprehensive or even systemic perspective of the contexts, the difficulty of reconciling the components, etc.
• ‚úÖ Define the role/function/posture/responsibility expected of the student for each of the selected contexts, in other words, for each level of competency development.
• ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê Exercise the targeted skills effectively over time.
• ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê Make relevant choices and implement them effectively, adapted to the professional situation encountered, including unpredictable situations.

SBA-C1-L1,SBA-C1-L1-P1,üî® Critical Learning 1Ô∏è‚É£ of Level 1Ô∏è‚É£‚≠ê,<div class=""container"">

column2: >Define the critical learnings to master in order to reach a given level of competency development.
>‚úçÔ∏è For each level of each competency, introduced by verbs with concise formulations.

column1: ‚úÖ Reflect on what the student must master to assume their role/function/posture/responsibility in terms of experimentation at this given level of competency development.
‚úÖ For each selected learning, identify the expected changes. These constitute the Critical Learnings (CL). For example:

column2: >In the CL (expected change) ""Researching for Progress"", it is expected that the student moves from using literature to simply justify their practices to using literature to really question their practices
>In the CL (expected change) ""Distinguishing Ends and Means"", it is expected that the student moves from action for the sake of action to action in service of a goal.

column1: ‚úÖ To ensure that the components can be evaluated, identify the significant indicators of each component's achievement.

‚úÖ To determine these indicators, think of a particular situation in which the students will be asked to apply their skills, and identify the elements to which you will pay attention to ensure that they have developed their skills in line with the components.

column2: >As a reminder, an indicator is an observable element, production or behavior that can be used to verify the quality of the result, the approach, compliance with standards/rules or the relationship with the various protagonists.&nbsp

column1: ‚úÖ To ensure that the components can be evaluated, identify the significant indicators of each component's achievement.

‚úÖ To determine these indicators, think of a particular situation in which the students will be asked to apply their skills, and identify the elements to which you will pay attention to ensure that they have developed their skills in line with the components.

column2: >As a reminder, an indicator is an observable element, production or behavior that can be used to verify the quality of the result, the approach, compliance with standards/rules or the relationship with the various protagonists.&nbsp
>Define indicator for competency development and assessment

>‚úçÔ∏è Writing the indicator directly into the competency framework can be facultive, depending on how you plan to evaluate and assess through activitivies, tests, productions, assessment grids, etc.
>Whether the indicator are present or not inside the Competency Framework, they would mostly help to operationalize criteria and assessment through&nbsp
column7: Competency</kbd>, then articulate them within specific <kbd>ü¶ø&nbsp
column8: Learning and Assessment Situation (LAS), delivrables, etc.

>‚úçÔ∏è Writing the indicator directly into the competency framework can be facultive, depending on how you plan to evaluate and assess through activitivies, tests, productions, assessment grids, etc.
>Whether the indicator are present or not inside the Competency Framework, they would mostly help to operationalize criteria and assessment through&nbsp
column7: Competency</kbd>, then articulate them within specific <kbd>ü¶ø&nbsp
column8: Learning and Assessment Situation (LAS), delivrables, etc.

column1: ‚úÖ To ensure that the components can be evaluated, identify the significant indicators of each component's achievement.

‚úÖ To determine these indicators, think of a particular situation in which the students will be asked to apply their skills, and identify the elements to which you will pay attention to ensure that they have developed their skills in line with the components.
